description: Erection of single storey detached residential annexe in rear garden
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Notwithstanding Section 55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) and the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and re enacting that Order with or without modification), the outbuilding to which this permission relates shall only be used for a purpose ancillary or incidental to the use of the site as a single family dwelling and for no other purposes whatsoever.Reason: The acceptability of the development is highly dependent upon the exact nature of the use of the building and to protect the amenities of neighbouring residential occupiers as required by Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any windows in the south-east (rear) elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The noise rating level of the heat pump condensor unit equipment hereby approved as part of this development will be at least 5dB below the background level, at all times, as measured from the nearest sensitive facades. Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of adjoining residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments, including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling within Flood Zone 2.Consultations8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Flood Risk.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: WhiLst officer acknowledge that the proposed first floor extension is not a common type of development in the vicinity of Thornhill Road, the extensions would relate well to the host property and it would not be visible from the streetscene. The applicant proposes to use matching materials, preventing a stark difference from the host dwelling and officers note that the proposed development would generally be designed to respect the character of the original dwelling with the proposed pitched roof, as such would appear as a subordinate and appropriate addition to the host property. Overall, there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and it is would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and designAmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The applicant has sufficiently demonstrated the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed first floor rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rules and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting and modest size of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts.Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).  Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why the development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Site and SurroundingsThe application site is a detached residential dwelling located to south of Wilton Grove, New Malden.The surrounding area is predominantly residential in character and appearance. The site is not located in a conservation area and the building and curtilage are not statutorily or locally listed.5 neighbouring properties have been notified with no responses received. Planning HistoryAny relevant planning history for the site has been taken into account in considering this application and recent planning history is available to view on the Council's website.The key areas of assessment are:Design Impact on neighbour amenityFire StrategyDesign Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officers Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension replaces an existing conservatory and extends the full width of the dwelling to a depth of approximately 3.9m and a height of approximately 3m. This extension is considered appropriate in design and proportionate in scale to the host dwelling. The materials comprise a mix of render walls and black aluminium panels to the rear elevation. A new roof is proposed to the existing side extension. The roof would be raised to a modest degree but this is not considered to result in any design concerns and the additional height would not be visible behind the existing parapet. The existing garage door is to be replaced by a window. This new opening is considered compatible with the existing dwelling and raises no design concerns. For these reasons, the proposal is in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8 and DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).Neighbour AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer's comment: The site is adjoined by 5 Wilton Grove to the east and 7 Wilton Grove to the west.With regard to 5 Wilton Grove, the proposed single storey extension does not extend beyond the existing conservatory but has a flat roof and is higher at the neighbour boundary (3m) than the conservatory (approximately 2.3m). Given the modest depth and additional height, the proposal is not considered to be overbearing for this neighbour. With regard to No. 7 Wilton Grove, this neighbour has an existing outbuilding sited on the boundary of the application site and so, for this reason, as well as the reasonable height and depth of the extension, the ground floor extension is not considered overbearing for this neighbour. The same conclusion is reached for the new roof of the side extension which raises the building by approximately 0.2m.Based on the submitted drawings, officers have undertaken a 45 degree elevation test which demonstrates that the proposal would not interrupt the midpoint of the nearest habitable window to either neighbour. It can therefore be concluded that the proposal would not result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight to neighbours. The proposal is not considered to result in an undue loss of privacy for either adjoining neighbour.In summary, the proposal is not considered to unduly affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties and the proposal is in accordance with Policy DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.HighwaysThe existing garage is to be alrered to a garage/storage. It is unclear whether any off street parking is being lost. However, regardless, the existing dwelling benefits from a large forecourt parking area. On this basis, there is considered adequate space remaining on site for parking to avoid an unacceptable impact on highway safety. SummaryOverall the development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and as such, planning permission is recommended for approval, subject to the conditions listed above.

This is for a deed of variation to amend a legal agreement attached to planning permission 08/16113/OUT. The Deed of Variation only amends the mortgagee's indemnity clause and does not contain any substantive amendments to the previous legal agreement. The Council's legal team has advised that the clause is now fairly standard and acceptable to lenders. Such requests are fairly common as the previous format has resulted in Registered Social Landlords having difficulty in finding funding.For these reasons, the Deed of Variation is considered acceptable.
Please re-title the Existing Plans sheet as there are no First, Second Floor or Roof Plan drawings.
Due to a system error any documents that may have been submitted via the web site are now irretrievable. We would be grateful if you could submit any documents again via email.

The fee required for your planning application is £174.00.  Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website, via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002, or by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames.
